section.title: Linear Transformations and Geometry

subsection.title: Transformations in the Plane
subsection.p: Transformations from \mathbb{R}^2 to \mathbb{R}^2 are transformations of the plane, and so correspond to transformations of vectors (equivalently, points) (x,y) in the plane. They are represented by 2 \times 2 matrices, of the form,
For various values of a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}. Then, a vector \vec{v} = (x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 is transformed by,
subsection.me: \begin{bmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} ax + by \\ cx + dy \end{bmatrix}
subsection.example:
Identity transformation
The most basic transformation is the identity transformation, which does not change any vector. That is, T(\vec{v}) = \vec{v} for every \vec{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2. To determine the matrix of this transformation, consider the images T(\vec{e}_1), T(\vec{e}_2). Of course, we should have,
T(\vec{e}_1) = \vec{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \qquad \text{and} \qquad T(\vec{e}_2) = \vec{e}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}
Thus, the matrix of T is,
\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix} = I_2
which is the 2 \times 2 identity matrix. This is pretty intuitive.
